title: Re: Moving back

Now *that* is more complex.

As it is noted; light can travel at c through a vacum Light slows down in normal materials because each photon is being absorbed by electrons for brief periods before being emitted again; so not only is it zigzagging, its also being stopped for short whiles.

Whereas going *faster* than c makes use of quantum phenomena; in this case the light particle aquires wavelike qualities; it is not in one unique location, you could say it bl;inks from place to place, without going through all that space in between.

Speed is a difficult word, we think we know what it means, but atoms are a bit more forgetful.A proud member of the Spleen Extinction society

[quote]Quote:[hr]
The speed of light is always constant; its one of the few things that is.
[hr][/quote]
Incorrect. When light goes through a substance (IE: Glass) it slows down, which is what causes refraction.

Actually, you find the Index of Refraction by knowing:

C = the speed of light in a vacuum
V = the speed of the light through your substance
N = Index of Refraction

N = C/V


Which leads us to Snell's Law:

N1*Sin(AngleInitial) = N2*Sin(AngleAfterPassingThroughSubstance)~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

[quote]Quote:[hr]Incorrect. When light goes through a substance (IE: Glass) it slows down, which is what causes refraction.[hr][/quote]

Incorrect, did you read my previous posts?

In these materials light is interacting with electrons, that is it si being contantly abosrbed and emmitted. The laws of probbability say that if this occurs randomly at large scales [larger than two wavelengths of light] it will appear as if the light has passed through the substance in a straight line.

You can think of it as a tennis ball being tossed from person to person in a room full of people, it moves at speed c when being chucked, but everytime someone catches it they hold it for a few seconds, making it seem as if it is moving slower.

Another prediction of this is that every single shadow should have a small bright point in its middle. At the time this was considered ridiculous, and it took years for the point to be detected.


However, it is thus possible for something to move faster than lights apparent speed in a medium; this will cause a photic boom, simalar to a sonic boom; neutrino detectors made of swimmingpools of bleach solution rely on this mechanism to work.

The speed of light is inviolate.

title: Re: time
content: I thought that was because as you approach the speed of light, time (for you) slows down, so when you see a light shining past you that light is running in normal time, therefore from your point of view it's moving much faster than you are - hence light always seems to travel at the same speed no matter where you're observing from.  It's not light that changes its speed, it's time that changes speed.
